text: today on x cast sources close to
Pakistan's military chief say he is
considering pulling back his military's
cooperation with the United States so
why does the u.s. continue giving
Pakistan billions of dollars in aid what
happened two days and op-ed columnist
Nicholas D Christoph on how education
can counter extremism in Pakistan on
Friday morning more than 80 Pakistani
soldiers were killed when at least one
suicide bomber blew himself up in a
military training center in northwest
Pakistan and while Pakistan's military
casualties in the war against terrorism
mount the United States is putting
increasing pressure on Pakistan's
military chief General Ashfaq Parvez
Kayani to do more at the end of the
Pakistani army general kayani is the
most powerful man in Pakistan he had a
complicated relationship with the United
States in the last three years he's been
quoted assiduously by top American
military officials General Petraeus who
have tried to persuade the general that
attend Pakistan's best interests and of
course in American best interest that he
turned on a group of militants who are
holed up in North Waziristan they're
known as the Afghan Taliban or the
Hakone network and these militants cross
into Afghanistan and kill American and
NATO soldiers in the war there we
Americans have been singularly
unsuccessful in persuading General
Kayani to do this the irritation with
the Pakistanis in Washington has become
increasingly more from General Kayani
point of view he feels his first loyalty
is to his truth who in many instances
question the American alliance and among
the lower rank even sympathetic to the
militants and perhaps more sympathetic
to the militants and they are to the
United States we don't know precisely
where Darrell kiani is going to come out
in the coming weeks in the sense that he
was under tremendous pressure from the
United States to take out for militant
leaders and as far as we can see he is
unwilling to
do this because he thinks it would be
very costly in terms of reprisals from
those groups I think he still wants to
continue the relationship with the
United States I think user wants to
accept money from the United States but
on different terms the United States
gives between two and three billion
dollars a year to Pakistan some in
reimbursement for counterterrorism
operations some to support the military
some and development aid but the big
question is whether or not it makes
sense to continue financing Pakistan to
that degree while there are so many
difficulties in winning Pakistani
loyalties and that's the argument that's
going to take place in Congress adding
to the complications of this are two
realities the first is the United States
moves a huge amount of its supplies into
Afghanistan through Pakistani territory
that means food it means fuel it means
ammunition until the American presence
in Afghanistan is reduced that need
isn't going away and the second problem
is the Pakistani nuclear program the US
has helped finance a covert program in
Pakistan to help make sure that those
nuclear weapons are safe but the
Pakistanis have never led american
officials very close to the pakistani
weapons themselves or even to the
laboratories where they're making so
much nuclear material they fear of
course that the US would swoop in
someday and sees that material or those
weapons and so the u.s. is going on
pakistani assurances that in fact there
are sufficient protections built in
place after the successful american raid
on bin Laden's compound I'm we are 35
miles from the capital of Islamabad many
here and many in Pakistan question
whether or not the security around those
nuclear weapons is as great as Pakistan
has long advertised
while Pakistan spends about a quarter of
its budget on its military it spends
less than 2% on its education system one
of the basic problems in Pakistan is
that the country tends to perceive its
threat is coming from the eastern border
from India and so many of the country's
resources are focused on its nuclear
capability on sending troops on Indian
border but maybe the broadest threat in
Pakistan is simply the lack of
development and above all the illiteracy
in Pakistan what happened to the death
for a country that had done reasonably
well since the 1970s education has just
been at a standstill you travel around
Pakistan you run into ghost schools that
just don't exist or you run into schools
where the students have shown up but the
teachers haven't in that kind of
environment you are going to see
continued instability continued
radicalism and it seems to me that what
Pakistan at the end of the day needs for
its own security and stability right now
isn't more nuclear weapons it's more
schools
